results.relevance_explanation: The work as a gas station worker involves tasks such as cashier work, lottery sales, dishwashing, unloading and shelving goods, and cleaning. These tasks are not directly related to the Ensihoitaja (AMK) curriculum or the healthcare industry. While the work provides valuable general skills, it doesn't align with the degree's focus on emergency care and medical services.
results.calculation_breakdown: 1 month (24.7.2017 - 1.9.2017) full-time (160 hours) / 27 hours per ECTS = 5.92 credits, rounded down to 5.0 credits, capped at 10.0 maximum for general training.
results.summary_justification: The work experience as a gas station worker provides valuable transferable skills such as customer service, handling transactions, and maintaining cleanliness. These skills are beneficial but not directly related to the Ensihoitaja (AMK) degree requirements. This experience contributes towards the practical training requirement as general training. The student will need additional degree-related professional training to complete the remaining credits.
results.conclusion: Student receives 5.0 ECTS credits as general training. This leaves 25.0 ECTS credits remaining for the 30-credit practical training requirement. Since general training is capped at 10 ECTS, the student has 5 ECTS credits remaining for general training and must complete at least 20 ECTS through professional training.
